articles.headline: Black Homeowners Struggle to Get Insurers to Pay Claims
articles.snippet: Black policyholders suspect discrimination as they deal with insurers, but it is impossible to prove because the insurers keep a lid on claims data.
articles.abstract: Black policyholders suspect discrimination as they deal with insurers, but it is impossible to prove because the insurers keep a lid on claims data.
articles.lead_paragraph: When a pipe burst and flooded her home in 2018, Deonne Burgess knew the cleanup would be messy. What she didn’t expect was the scrutiny from State Farm, her home insurance provider.

articles.headline: Another Arrest, and Jail Time, Due to a Bad Facial Recognition Match
articles.snippet: A New Jersey man was accused of shoplifting and trying to hit an officer with a car. He is the third known Black man to be wrongfully arrested based on face recognition.
articles.abstract: A New Jersey man was accused of shoplifting and trying to hit an officer with a car. He is the third known Black man to be wrongfully arrested based on face recognition.
articles.lead_paragraph: In February 2019, Nijeer Parks was accused of shoplifting candy and trying to hit a police officer with a car at a Hampton Inn in Woodbridge, N.J. The police had identified him using facial recognition software, even though he was 30 miles away at the time of the incident.

articles.headline: Cryptocurrency Start-Up Underpaid Women and Black Employees, Data Shows
articles.snippet: An analysis of internal pay data at the San Francisco company Coinbase shows disparities that were much larger than those in the tech industry.
articles.abstract: An analysis of internal pay data at the San Francisco company Coinbase shows disparities that were much larger than those in the tech industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: The fast-growing cryptocurrency start-up Coinbase has been rattled in recent months by tensions between executives and employees who said they were being treated unfairly because of their race or gender.

articles.headline: Louisville Officer Who Shot Breonna Taylor Will Be Fired
articles.snippet: Detective Myles Cosgrove will be terminated along with Detective Joshua Jaynes, who was involved in planning the deadly raid.
articles.abstract: Detective Myles Cosgrove will be terminated along with Detective Joshua Jaynes, who was involved in planning the deadly raid.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Louisville police officer who fired the shot that killed Breonna Taylor, a Black emergency room technician whose death set off a wave of protests on American streets, was told on Tuesday that the department was moving to oust him from the force, as was a second officer who obtained a judge’s approval for the poorly planned nighttime raid on her home.

articles.headline: China Has All It Needs to Vaccinate Millions, Except Any Approved Vaccines
articles.snippet: Across the country, local governments plan to inoculate 50 million people against the coronavirus by early next year. But the vaccines have not officially been approved.
articles.abstract: Across the country, local governments plan to inoculate 50 million people against the coronavirus by early next year. But the vaccines have not officially been approved.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hospitals all over China have almost everything necessary for a mass coronavirus vaccination drive: Millions of doses. Refrigerators to store them. Health care workers trained to administer them.

articles.headline: Biden Criticizes Trump on Vaccine Distribution and Pledges to Pick Up Pace
articles.snippet: Three weeks from taking office, Joe Biden called vaccinating Americans “the greatest operational challenge we’ve ever faced as a nation” and offered a bleak assessment of the months ahead.
articles.abstract: Three weeks from taking office, Joe Biden called vaccinating Americans “the greatest operational challenge we’ve ever faced as a nation” and offered a bleak assessment of the months ahead.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. on Tuesday criticized the speed of vaccine distribution under the Trump administration and promised to step up the pace when he takes office, while delivering a sober warning about the toll of the coronavirus pandemic.
articles.byline: By Thomas Kaplan and Rebecca Robbins

articles.headline: McConnell Blocks Vote on $2,000 Checks Despite G.O.P. Pressure
articles.snippet: Senator Mitch McConnell instead provided vague assurances that the Senate would “begin the process” of discussing the checks and two other issues that the president demanded lawmakers address.
articles.abstract: Senator Mitch McConnell instead provided vague assurances that the Senate would “begin the process” of discussing the checks and two other issues that the president demanded lawmakers address.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Mitch McConnell blocked an attempt by Democrats on Tuesday to hold an immediate vote on increasing stimulus checks to $2,000 from $600, leaving the fate of the measure unclear as President Trump continued to demand the larger payouts and more Republicans publicly endorsed the idea.

articles.headline: U.K. Authorizes Covid-19 Vaccine From Oxford and AstraZeneca
articles.snippet: Health officials hope to soon vaccinate up to two million people per week as the country’s hospitals are overwhelmed by cases of a new, more contagious coronavirus variant.
articles.abstract: Health officials hope to soon vaccinate up to two million people per week as the country’s hospitals are overwhelmed by cases of a new, more contagious coronavirus variant.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Britain on Wednesday became the first country to give emergency authorization to the coronavirus vaccine developed by AstraZeneca and the University of Oxford, clearing the path for a cheap and easy-to-store shot that much of the world will rely on to help end the pandemic.
articles.byline: By Benjamin Mueller and Rebecca Robbins

articles.headline: Argentina Legalizes Abortion, a Milestone in a Conservative Region
articles.snippet: The Senate vote on Wednesday was a major victory for Latin America’s growing feminist movement, and its ripple effects are likely to be widespread.
articles.abstract: The Senate vote on Wednesday was a major victory for Latin America’s growing feminist movement, and its ripple effects are likely to be widespread.
articles.lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — Argentina on Wednesday became the largest nation in Latin America to legalize abortion, a landmark vote in a conservative region and a victory for a grass-roots movement that turned years of rallies into political power.
articles.byline: By Daniel Politi and Ernesto Londoño

articles.headline: 25 Days That Changed the World: How Covid-19 Slipped China’s Grasp
articles.snippet: Beijing acted against the coronavirus with stunning force, as its official narratives recount. But not before a political logjam had allowed a local outbreak to kindle a global pandemic.
articles.abstract: Beijing acted against the coronavirus with stunning force, as its official narratives recount. But not before a political logjam had allowed a local outbreak to kindle a global pandemic.
articles.lead_paragraph: The most famous doctor in China was on an urgent mission.
